text: Climate activists have glued themselves to one of Britain’s best-known works of art after masking it with a different image in a protest at the National Gallery.
Just Stop Oil protesters attached themselves to the frame of The Hay Wain, by John Constable, and overlaid the painting with a “reimagined” dystopian vision of the scene.

The artwork, completed in 1821, shows an idyllic vision of the millpond at Flatford on the River Stour in Suffolk. According to the group, the new print “depicts a nightmare scene that demonstrates how oil will destroy our countryside”.

text: Climate protesters glued themselves to the frame of a Van Gogh painting at Somerset House in London yesterday.

Visitors watched as two people from the Just Stop Oil group attached themselves to Peach Trees in Blossom, a 19th-century work in the Courtauld Gallery. The area around the painting was cordoned off by gallery staff during the protest and the museum was then closed.
A man and a woman were arrested for criminal damage, the Metropolitan Police said.
Just Stop Oil, which has protested at oil terminals and government offices, said it was calling for art institutions to join the group in “civil resistance” against climate change.

text: Alfa Romeo’s Zhou Guanyu miraculously escaped unharmed from a horrific crash at the British Grand Prix during a dramatic opening lap which also featured environmental activists invading the track.

At the first corner of an incident-packed race at Silverstone, which was won by Ferrari’s Carlos Sainz, Zhou, the 23-year-old Chinese driver, clipped George Russell’s Mercedes, flipped upside down and skidded off the track.

With its progress barely halted by the trackside gravel, the car flew over the tyre barrier before coming to rest, crumpled, against the perimeter fence. text: Sweden has Greta Thunberg, Britain has Jack Harries. The documentary film-maker and climate activist, 29, is the Harry Styles of the environmental movement: he has interviewed Barack Obama and Sir David Attenborough, and amassed 1.3 million followers on Instagram and 3.7 million subscribers on YouTube, with beautifully shot films of Earth in peril. Yet some of the user comments are less about carbon footprints and more about his looks: “Whaddababe”; “Sexy eco-warrior” etc.

text: On the start line of the coxless four final at the London 2012 Olympics, Peter Reed heard a roar from the crowd echo 2,000 metres down the lake, filling his ears and his spirit. It felt like the entire nation was cheering on the British crew.

Sitting there with oar in hand, Reed could not have been in a better state. Physically, this 6ft 6ins colossus of superhuman power and endurance had never felt stronger. Mentally, he felt invincible. “Forgive the apparent lack of humility,” Reed says, “but sitting on the start line, I felt sorry for the other boats.”
